metadata.subject: Crime Victims' Rights During Criminal Investigations? Applying the Crime Victims' Rights Act Before Criminal Charges Are Filed

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida
Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology

relationships.description: Epstein sexually abused Jane Doe Number One
Epstein sexually abused Jane Doe Number Two
Entered into nonprosecution agreement with Epstein
Kyl objected to DOJ's interpretation of CVRA in letter to Holder

analysis.purpose: To argue that the Crime Victims' Rights Act applies before formal charges are filed and critique the DOJ's contrary position
analysis.significance: Addresses a critical timing issue in victims' rights that determines whether victims can participate in plea negotiations and nonprosecution agreements

notable_quotes: "When Congress enacted the CVRA, it intended to protect crime victims throughout the criminal justice processâ€”from the investigative phases to the final conclusion of a case." - Senator Jon Kyl
"The statutory language clearly contemplates pre-charge proceedings." - Does v. United States
"Too often victims of crime experience a secondary victimization at the hands of the criminal justice system." - Senator Jon Kyl
red_flags: Potential for revictimization through justice process exclusion

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this academic legal analysis

illegal_activity.description: Document is an academic legal analysis discussing legal interpretations and case law, not evidence of first-hand illegal activity

public_knowledge.context: Academic journal article published in widely accessible law review, discussing public legal issues and high-profile cases

analysis.summary: This law journal article argues that the Crime Victims' Rights Act applies during criminal investigations before formal charges are filed, using the Jeffrey Epstein case as a key example where victims were excluded from nonprosecution agreement discussions. The authors critique the DOJ's contrary legal interpretation and propose a framework for when pre-charging rights should attach.
